snippet: The loan is intended to avert the collapse of the economy, which has been crumbling since the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak....
abstract: International Monetary Fund approves $12 billion loan for Egypt, move meant to avert economic collapse as country contends with falling currency, soaring inflation and food shortages; some experts warn loan is first of several painful yet necessary steps to stabilize economy and say conditions may worsen in short term.

byline.contributor: Nour Youssef contributed reporting from Cairo, and Declan Walsh from New York.

lead_paragraph: The loan is intended to avert the collapse of the economy, which has been crumbling since the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

headline.main: Painful Steps Help Egypt Secure $12 Billion I.M.F. Loan
headline.print_headline: Egypt Gets I.M.F. Loan, but Cost Will Be Painful
